hints.content:
Let's interpret the frequency table.

Measurement | Number of Eagles 
- | - 
$80$| $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid} = 5$ eagles
$82\text{ cm}$ | $\mid\mid\mid = 3$ eagles
$82\dfrac{1}{2}\text{ cm}$ | $\mid\mid = 2$ eagles
$84\dfrac{1}{2}\text{ cm}$| $\mid\mid\mid = 3$ eagles
Each tick mark on the number line represents an interval of ${\dfrac{1}{2}\text { cm}}$.

There were $5$ eagles with a wingspan of $\blueD{80\text { cm}}$.  

So, we place $5$ dots over $\blueD{80}$ on the number line.   

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled lengths (centimeters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 80, 81, 82, 83, 84, and 85. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 5 dots above 80. !

hints.content: Now, let's graph the other measurements on the frequency table.

The correctly graphed measurements are:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled lengths (centimeters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 80, 81, 82, 83, 84, and 85. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 5 dots above 80, 3 dots above 82, 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 82 and 83, and 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 84 and 85. !

question.content:
The nature center measured the wingspan of all their eagles to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{2} \text{ cm}$. 

Measurement | Number of Eagles
- | - 
$80\text{ cm}$| $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}$
$82\text{ cm}$ | $\mid\mid\mid$
$82\dfrac{1}{2}\text{ cm}$ | $\mid\mid$
$84\dfrac{1}{2}\text{ cm}$| $\mid\mid\mid$


**Graph the measurements from the frequency table on the following line plot.**   
*Click above the line plot to make dots for each of the measurements.*
[[☃ plotter 1]]
